Authors:
Slavomir Adamcik, Brian Patrick Looney, Joshua Mark
Birkebak, Sona Jancovicova, Katarina Adamcikova, Patrick Brandon
Matheny
Title:
Species circumscription of naphthalene smelling Hodophilus
(Clavariaceae, Agaricales) in North America
Keywords:
agaricoid, Clavariaceae, multi-locus phylogeny,
morphology, type studies
Abstract:
Five North American Hodophilus species with an unpleasant
naphthalene-like odour are now recognized based on sequence and/or
morphological data and molecular annotation of type collections. Two
well-supported eastern North American species clades do not match any of
the studied types and are described here as new species Hodophilus
hesleri and Hodophilus smithii. The previously described Hodophilus
paupertinus is found to represent an autonomous species and appears
restricted to western North America. The previously described Hodophilus
subfuscescens is an independent lineage found in eastern North America.
A morphological type study of Hodophilus peckianus shows that it is a
distinct species and not represented among recent collections.
Multi-locus phylogenetic analyses of European and North American
material of naphthalene-like smelling species reveal no species with
transatlantic distributions. Overall, Hodophilus comprises two
superclades (the Hodophilus foetens superclade and the Hodophilus
micaceus superclade) and 16 terminal clades that correspond to
phylogenetic species. This study introduces a new approach for
morphological delimitation of agaricoid Clavariaceae combining shape and
dimensions of particular elements in the pileipellis of hymeniderm type
and caulocystidia on the stipe surface. A diagnostic key to North
American naphthalene-smelling Hodophilus species is provided. All
previously described taxa included in this study that were previously
treated in the genus Hygrophorus, Camarophyllopsis or Hygrotrama and are
formally transferred here to the genus Hodophilus.
